content.description:
This is the striking lone splitter up the left side of the April Fools stump. Easily spotted from the road with a pair of 'nocs.

The start begins with easy climbin over a soft looking but solid pillar with cracks on either side. Mantel the pillar and begin the journey up a tight #1's that tapers to 0.75's eventually climbing baggy 0.5's ending in a pod, and finishing on fingers with a fun sequence to finish the route.

This thing is a zinger.
content.protection: A hand full each of #1's, 0.75's, 0.5's. One or two each 0.4, 0.3. All camalot sizing if you didn't know that already. The pod takes hands to fist's but you'll only need one piece for it.
content.location: Left side of the April fools stump. You can't miss it.

content.description:
Start with a thin hands crack and mantel onto some loose blocks. Atop the loose blocks climb the left crack on hands to wide hands to a double bolt belay in the chimney. Second pitch stems the chimney, and surmounts the roof.

This and Fools Gold are switched in order in the Bjornstad guide book.
content.location: At the base of the stump just down the slope from Mean Weener.

content.description:
Worth doing if you're in the area. P1 stays shady later, but P2 gets sun several hours earlier than Mean Weener. Plaque currently says Fools Rush In. There's already a route of this name at the cliff, so this should be changed.

P1 - is the obvious, left facing corner on the left side of April Fools Wall. This corner is fairly distinct from the road.

Begin with slightly chossy rock that gets much better around the 20 foot mark. Follow the corner system  ~100 feet to the top of the ledge. Chain Anchor

P2 -  trends up and left off the ledge face climbing past a few drilled angles and bolts. A red C3 sized piece (or maybe a similar sized offset alien) feels pretty crucial for clipping the first bolt over the bulge. Then move left into the obvious crack system and follow it to the anchor on top of the next ledge. Some cruxy face moves plus some wideness towards the top of the pitch keep it interesting. Consider bringing some backup webbing for this anchor. You can rap this pitch with one 70meter rope. I dont think a 60m will reach the ledge.

P3  fairly short pitch. Aid up thin crack that gradually widens into free climbing terrain and ends at a bolted anchor at a stance below the wide crack.

P4  get your wide game on. I mostly aided this on #5s and 6s. Ended the pitch fairly short due to waning daylight. I think you might be able to rap to the P2 anchor with one 70M.

P5+? Unclimbed. Wideness and loose blocks. Have at it if you want some more adventure.
content.protection:
Pitches 1 & 2:

single set C3s

double set cams .3 - #3 C4

2 extra .75 & #1 C4s for

1 x #4 C4

If going higher, bring multiples in the green & purple C3 sizes plus multiple #5 & 6 C4s
content.location: Begins with the obvious left facing corner on the left side of the April Fool's Wall (see beta pic).

climbs.name: Fool's Gold
climbs.fa: Dave Anderson, Keith Royster, James Garrett, Will Gilmer. April 1st, 1990.

content.description:
An obvious and aesthetic line that climbs a right-leaning wide hands / fist crack.

Starts on ~10 feet of lower-quality rock but quickly gives way to a glorious splitter in solid stone.
content.location: On the south side of the April Fools formation, around the corner (climbers right) from Fools Rush In.
